newsitem.title: UK: Commodity fall eases off, markets draw breath.
newsitem.headline: Commodity fall eases off, markets draw breath.

text.p: Key commodity markets mostly ebbed lower on Tuesday but declines were gentler and activity was light as traders took a breather after Monday's dramatic fund sell-off.
Cocoa, the biggest victim on Monday, extended its losses in early trade on further fund and speculative selling before trade buying helped prices bottom out in the London afternoon.
On the London Metal Exchange (LME) a reprieve from Monday's heavy duty fund sell-off saw copper prices push higher and other base metals steady.
Cocoa was given a leg-up when heavy sales failed to emerge at New York's open and trade interest, speckled with light speculative buying, rippled into the market to bargain-hunt, traders said.
May futures ended at 972 stg per tonne.
But traders were not yet convinced prices were ready to go higher. They said the market was only pausing after Monday's drop.
Coffee had a quiet day, shedding just $5 to reach $1,570 per tonne on the London May contract for robusta types.
Meanwhile, the flagship LME three month copper contract rose $14 to $2,292 per tonne helped by a drop in world stocks.
Zinc also edged higher on solid foundations laid in morning trade and pushed higher after New York opened to reach $1,260 per tonne, up $13.
But some LME traders said they were on guard for more fund activity over the next few days.
The base metals all managed to keep their heads above water save aluminium alloy which slipped $11 to $1,474 per tonne.
The precious metals split two ways.
Palladium was again the star performer and built on Monday's gains to reach $156 an ounce, up $2.50.
Fuelling the rise is continued delay in Russia over renegotiating sale contracts to Japan, the world's biggest buyer, after they expired at the beginning of the year.
"It scuppered any plans of getting palladium into Japan," one London dealer said of the strike. "Even if they did start re-supplying there would be a lot of (backlog of) demand in Japan."
Platinum picked up on palladium's coat tails to inch higher.
But silver led the way on the downside, slipping to $4.78 an ounce before recovering to end the day unchanged at $4.80 an ounce.
Gold also suffered some selling pressure and dealers saw its outlook capped given the dollar's gains against the yen and the mark.
Bullion dipped to $348.85 an ounce in London, down from the morning fix of $349.10 an ounce.
IPE Brent crude oil edged higher in what traders and brokers said was a technical bounce following recent sharp falls. Brent May futures climbed 12 cents to $17.88 per barrel by 1745 GMT.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, wheat got off to a good start with May futures up more than five cents to $3.86 per bushel early.
